title: 109_hr3191
content: The Act may be cited as the "Multilateral Debt Relief Act of 2005". The Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative was created in 1996 to reduce debt burden in impoverished countries. Donor countries have committed over $50 billion in debt cancellation. Countries receiving relief have increased poverty reduction expenditures by 75% on average. Congress has shown support for debt relief initiatives. Congress has demonstrated support for bilateral and multilateral debt relief through comprehensive initiatives enacted in 1999 and 2000. Several countries, including the United States, have canceled bilateral loans for countries eligible for debt relief under the Enhanced HIPC Initiative. However, some countries will still owe substantial debts to international financial institutions. The Enhanced HIPC Initiative aims to cancel 100% of debt owed by eligible countries to multilateral institutions, allowing for increased investments in infrastructure and social programs to achieve sustainable economic growth and the Millennium Development Goals. On June 11, 2005, finance ministers from the Group of 8 proposed canceling $40 billion in debt owed by 18 countries immediately, with a total of $56 billion in debt canceled for 38 countries. This would save each country an average of $1.5 billion annually in debt service payments. Donors would provide additional resources to the World Bank and African Development Bank for grants and lending to the poorest countries for investments in health, education, and well-being. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "eligible country" refers to a country meeting specific government criteria. "Enhanced HIPC Initiative" and "HIPC Initiative" are defined as specific programs aimed at reducing poverty. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of various international financial institutions such as the World Bank, International Monetary Fund, and others. It also defines the members of the Group of 8 countries. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to cancel 100% of debts owed by eligible countries to international financial institutions. This authority is in addition to other debt relief measures and may require appropriations from the President if other countries contribute funds. The Secretary of the Treasury should pursue debt relief for eligible countries. Contributions to multilateral development banks are also addressed in the International Development Association Act. The United States Governor of the Association is authorized to contribute to the fourteenth replenishment of the resources of the Association, subject to appropriations. For this contribution, appropriations are authorized as necessary for payment by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, the African Development Fund Act is amended to include provisions for the tenth replenishment. SEC. 218. TENTH REPLENISHMENT. The United States Governor of the Fund is authorized to contribute to the tenth replenishment of the Fund's resources, subject to appropriations. Appropriations are authorized as necessary for payment by the Secretary of the Treasury. Authorization of appropriations for the Enhanced HIPC Initiative is granted to the President to fulfill commitments made by the United States. Additionally, reports to Congress are required. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress every 180 days on negotiations for debt relief for impoverished countries not covered by previous initiatives. The appropriate congressional committees are defined as the Committee on Appropriations and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate, and the Committee on Appropriations and the Committee on International Relations of the House of Representatives.
